text: I suggested GPL and AGPL. Are there any others that you would suggest?

text: `EUPL-1.2` can be used by anyone. There isn’t any European requirement just as no one needs to be or has been affiliated with MIT to use the MIT license. The EU has tried to get more adoption of the license within and outside Europe but the copyleft has been a big deterrent.

elements.text: can be used by anyone. There isn’t any European requirement just as no one needs to be or has been affiliated with MIT to use the MIT license. The EU has tried to get more adoption of the license within and outside Europe but the copyleft has been a big deterrent.

text: Yup, but there are certain benefits to it that make it more useful for European projects, like that it's written with EU law in mind and available in all EU languages. Those benefits may not apply elsewhere, and you might be better off with (A-)GPL because it might be more established (also in courts).

elements.text: Yup, but there are certain benefits to it that make it more useful for European projects, like that it's written with EU law in mind and available in all EU languages. Those benefits may not apply elsewhere, and you might be better off with (A-)GPL because it might be more established (also in courts).

text: One clear benefit of EUPL-1.2 over GPL-3.0 and such is if the software is/was EU-funded. Many EU groups like to see that output will be EUPL licensed in tenders and such. Same for OSS developed by EU governments, which may prefer EUPL over (A-)GPL licenses for compliance bureaucracy.
